Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fjord Ecosystem Structure and Function on the West Antarctic Peninsula - Hotspots of Productivity and Biodiversity? (FjordEco)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Marine communities along the western Antarctic Peninsula are highly productive ecosystems which support a diverse assemblage of charismatic animals such as penguins, seals, and whales as well as commercial fisheries such as that on Antarctic krill. Fjords (long, narrow, deep inlets of the sea between high cliffs) along the central coast of the Peninsula appear to be intense, potentially climate sensitive, hotspots of biological production and biodiversity, yet the structure and dynamics of these fjord ecosystems are very poorly understood. Because of this intense biological activity and the charismatic fauna it supports, these fjords are also major destinations for a large Antarctic tourism industry. This project is an integrated field and modeling program to evaluate physical oceanographic processes, glacial inputs, water column community dynamics, and seafloor bottom community structure and function in these important yet little understood fjord systems. These Antarctic fjords have characteristics that are substantially different from well-studied Arctic fjords, likely yielding much different responses to climate warming. This project will provide major new insights into the dynamics and climate sensitivity of Antarctic fjord ecosystems, highlighting contrasts with Arctic sub-polar fjords, and potentially transforming our understanding of the ecological role of fjords in the rapidly warming west Antarctic coastal marine landscape. The project will also further the NSF goal of training new generations of scientists, providing scientific training for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students. This includes the unique educational opportunity for undergraduates to participate in research cruises in Antarctica and the development of a novel summer graduate course on fjord ecosystems. Internet based outreach activities will be enhanced and extended by the participation of a professional photographer who will produce magazine articles, websites, radio broadcasts, and other forms of public outreach on the fascinating Antarctic ecosystem.

This project will involve a 15-month field program to test mechanistic hypotheses concerning oceanographic and glaciological forcing, and phytoplankton and benthic community response in the Antarctic fjords. Those efforts will be followed by a coupled physical/biological modeling effort to evaluate the drivers of biogeochemical cycles in the fjords and to explore their potential sensitivity to enhanced meltwater and sediment inputs. Fieldwork over two oceanographic cruises will utilize moorings, weather stations, and glacial, sea-ice and seafloor time-lapse cameras to obtain an integrated view of fjord ecosystem processes. The field team will also make multiple shipboard measurements and will use towed and autonomous underwater vehicles to intensively evaluate fjord ecosystem structure and function during spring/summer and autumn seasons. These integrated field and modeling studies are expected to elucidate fundamental properties of water column and sea bottom ecosystem structure and function in the fjords, and to identify key physical-chemical-glaciological forcing in these rapidly warming ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP) harbors highly productive coastal ecosystems that support diverse assemblages of charismatic animals such as penguins, seals, and whales, as well as commercial krill fisheries. Glacier-hosting fjords along the central WAP coast appear to be particular hotspots of biological production and biodiversity and are major destinations for Antarctic tourism. However, the structure and dynamics of these fjord ecosystems have been very poorly studied even though they may be especially sensitive to climate warming. Our FjordEco Project integrated field and modeling studies in Andvord Bay fjord on the WAP to explore (1) how glacial and oceanographic processes enhance fjord productivity and biodiversity, and (2) how increased meltwater and sediment inputs resulting from climate warming may alter these productive ecosystems. The field program consisted of three research cruises over 16 months (Dec 2015 ? Mar 2017) to intensively evaluate fjord ecosystem structure and function. The project team deployed oceanographic moorings, weather stations, as well as glacial, sea-ice and seafloor time-lapse cameras, for the full 16 months to obtain an integrated view of fjord ecosystem processes. Field work also involved intensive shipboard measurements using a broad array of oceanographic sensors and sampling gear, including towed and autonomous underwater vehicles, ocean-turbulence sensors, nutrient measurements, plankton sampling, primary production assays, sediment coring, seafloor respirometry, and bottom trawling. Field data were then incorporated into coupled physical-biogeochemical models to simulate oceanographic conditions in the fjord and to evaluate important drivers of ecosystem structure and functions, including primary production and larval dispersal. 

Key findings of the FjordEco Project in Andvord Bay include the following. (1) The flux of glacial ice into Andvord Bay is high, with rapidly flowing glaciers (7 m/d) calving ~5 million tonnes of ice per day.  However, because warm Upper Circumpolar Deep Water from the open ocean penetrates little into Andvord Bay, there is minimal melting of glacial ice. As a consequence, glacial meltwater and sediments have limited influence on Andvord Bay compared to fjords in other polar regions, such as the Arctic, King George Island and other parts of the WAP.  (2) A combination of weak freshwater stratification and generally light winds in Andvord Bay provide favorable conditions for intense summer phytoplankton blooms, yielding massive summer deposition of food-rich phytoplankton detritus to the fjord floor. Resulting high food availability combined with little disturbance from glacial sedimentation promotes the development of rich and diverse seafloor communities in sediments and on drop stones in Andvord Bay compared to the open WAP continental shelf. (3) Occasional strong katabatic winds, observed during the field experiments and resolved by the models, were found to dominate the exchange of water between the fjord and the open shelf, exporting phytoplankton production from the fjord to the broader coastal zone. (4) Modeling of larval dispersal suggests that the rich seafloor communities in Andvord Bay and other WAP fjords may be important larval sources for the open WAP coast. (5) As climate warms along the WAP, ecosystem measurements and modeling suggest that meltwater influence and glacial sediment disturbance in Andvord Bay will increase substantially, lowering primary production and disturbing the rich fjord communities in the water column and at the seafloor (Figure 1).  Such changes could alter biodiversity in the WAP coastal zone generally, and reduce the appeal of Andvord Bay, and other fjords in the region, for Antarctic tourism.  In summary, our results indicate that Andvord Bay and other WAP fjords are biodiversity hotspots that are still in the early stages of ecosystem change resulting from climate warming, but are likely to be very sensitive to warming-driven increases in glacial meltwater and sediment inputs.

The broader impacts of this project are many and varied. The project trained two new PhDs and one postdoctoral scholar in Antarctic research. Thirteen young scientists (4 undergraduate students, 6 graduate students, and 5 early career scientists including 8 women) gained field research experience in Antarctica during the project. The project produced a high-resolution ecosystem model to simulate physical and biological processes in WAP fjords, and to elucidate their sensitivity to climate change. A 5-week, intensive summer field course on Fjord Ecosystems and Climate Change was developed at Friday Harbor Laboratories, USA, and a portion of this course was taught in Buenos Aires, Argentina, educating in total >60 graduate and postdoctoral students from at least eight countries on polar coastal ecosystems and climate-change impacts.  Our outreach activities, including laboratory open houses at the University of Hawaii and Florida State University, as well as web posts and presentations on Antarctic cruise ships, have informed thousands of members of the general public about the high productivity and diversity of West Antarctic Peninsula fjords, and their potential sensitivity to climate change.
